questions.text: A 65-year-old presents with visual blurring in the left eye, 20/40 vision, and a history of cataract surgery three months ago. Fundus examination shows retinal thickening and a dull foveal reflex. OCT and FFA findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman presents with gradual central vision loss in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals concentric rings of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea, creating a characteristic appearance. The image showing the appearance is given below: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be associated with this condition?

A 32-year-old female presents with difficulty seeing in low light and peripheral vision loss that has gradually worsened over several years. On fundoscopy, the following findings are noted. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?

A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with a white pupillary reflex in the right eye, noticed by the parents in flash photography. On examination, the child has strabismus. Which of the following is NOT a condition to be considered in the differential diagnosis of this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Leukocoria
  • Congenital cataract
  • Inflammatory deposits in vitreous following a plastic cyclitis or choroiditis,
  • Coloboma of the choroid,
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (Option C)
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (Option B)
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis
  • Exudative retinopathy of Coats (Option A)

Endophytic retinoblastoma
  • Tuberous sclerosis
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Astrocytoma

Exophytic Retinoblastoma
  • Exudative retinopathy of Coats

questions.text: In which layer of the retina, as labeled in the histology image, are the cell bodies of bipolar cells located?
questions.explanation:
Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer) (Option D)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer (Option C)

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer (Option B)

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer (Option A)

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) undergoes Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA), revealing pooling of dye under the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and leakage from newly formed vessels beneath the retina. What abnormality is most likely detected on FFA in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperfluorescence due to dye pooling under detached RPE and neovascularization

options.label: B
options.text: Hypofluorescence due to blockage of background fluorescence by retinal hemorrhage

options.label: C
options.text: Hypofluorescence due to occlusion of retinal vasculature

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperfluorescence due to staining of the optic disc

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperfluorescence due to dye pooling under detached RPE and neovascularization
questions.explanation:
Fluorescence Type

Cause

Examples

Hyperfluorescence

Window defect in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Atrophy showing background choroidal fluorescence

Pooling of dye under detached RPE

Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) (Option A)

Pooling of dye under sensory retina

Central serous retinopathy (CSR)

Leakage into the neurosensory retina due to the breakdown of the inner blood-retinal barrier

Cystoid macular edema (CME)

Leakage from choroidal or retinal neovascularization

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, subretinal neovascular membrane in ARMD

Staining (long retention of dye by tissues)

Drusen, normal optic disc (Option D)

Leakage from optic nerve head

Papilloedema

Hypofluorescence

Blockage of background fluorescence

Retinal hemorrhage (Option B), hard exudates, pigmented clumps

Occlusion of retinal/choroidal vasculature

Central retinal artery occlusion (Option C), diabetic retinopathy capillary occlusion

Loss of vasculature

Choroideremia, myopic degeneration

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes undergoes a fundus examination, revealing extensive retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, and moderate intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in one quadrant. What is the most appropriate follow-up interval for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

(Option D)

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

(Option C)

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months (Option B)

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months (Option A)

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)

Mild-moderate PDR

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease

Is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of severe headache and blurred vision. His blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy image is given below. Which of the following fundus changes is most characteristic of this diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Papilledema

Swelling of optic disc due to raised intracranial pressure and optic nerve ischemia

Exudates

Lipid deposits; may form a macular star

Retinal hemorrhages

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, especially in posterior pole

Cotton wool spots

Ischemic infarcts of nerve fiber layer

Venous dilation

Result of vascular congestion

Narrowing of arterioles

Severe vasospasm in acute cases

Elschnig’s spots

Black spots with yellow halos from choroidal infarcts

Siegrist’s streaks

Linear pigmentation along choroidal arterioles from fibrinoid necrosis

Feature

Chronic Hypertensive Retinopathy

Malignant Hypertensive Retinopathy

Arteriolar narrowing

Generalized or focal narrowing, A-V nicking (Option A)

Marked narrowing due to vasospasm

Retinal reflex changes

Copper-wiring (Option B), silver-wiring

Not prominent

Retinal hemorrhages

Few flame-shaped at posterior pole

Numerous flame-shaped hemorrhages

Exudates

Hard exudates, macular-star (Option D)

Focal intraretinal periarterial transudates (FIPTs)

Cotton wool spots

Present

More prominent and widespread

Choroidal involvement

Absent

Elschnig’s spots, Siegrist’s streaks

Optic neuropathy

Absent/minimal

Papilledema, optic nerve ischemia

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden, severe vision loss in his left eye. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is present. Fundus examination reveals the following changes: Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous Stasis Retinopathy)

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic Retinopathy)

Prevalence

75% of cases

25% of cases

Vision

Mild to moderate blurring

Severe, sudden vision loss

RAPD

Absent or mild

Present

Early Fundus Findings

Mild venous congestion, peripheral flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild/no macular edema

Massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema

Late Fundus Findings

Vein sheathing, cilioretinal collaterals, absorbed hemorrhages, chronic cystoid edema

Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Complications

15-30% convert to ischemic CRVO

Neovascular glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, proliferative retinopathy

Image

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with sudden distrubunce of vision in his right eye for two weeks. He reports distortion of images. He has been intermittently using corticosteroids for allergies. His Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18. FFA and OCT findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with worsening vision. Fundoscopy reveals retinal edema, microaneurysms, and hard exudates. Which of the following mechanisms is not responsible for the development of diabetic retinopathy?

A 64-year-old male with long-standing hypertension comes for a routine eye checkup. On fundoscopy, the ophthalmologist observes the following changes as shown in the image below. What is the most likely stage of hypertensive retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Key Features

Grade I (Option A)

Mild generalized arteriolar narrowing, broadening of the light reflex.
 

Grade II (Option B)

Focal arteriolar narrowing, A-V nicking (Salu’s sign)

Grade III (Option C)

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and more pronounced A-V nicking (Bonnet and Gunn signs), hemorrhages, and exudates.

Grade IV (Option D)

All features of Grade III + Papilledema, Silver-wiring of arterioles.
